game.title: IoT Strategy Sprint
game.subtitle: Learn IoT fundamentals through strategic decision-making

onboarding.title: Welcome to IoT Strategy Sprint
onboarding.intro: You are the Director of IoT Strategy for BrightWorks Operations. Your mission: use IoT to make the organization faster, greener, and safer—without creating complexity.

processSteps.senseDesc: Devices collect data from the environment

onboarding.whatYouDoDesc: Over 3 years, you'll allocate IoT tokens to different initiatives. Watch how your choices affect key metrics and learn the tradeoffs involved in IoT strategy.

dashboard.instructions: Allocate your tokens to IoT initiatives. Each card can receive 0-3 tokens.
dashboard.reallocationAlert: You can reallocate 50% of your previous tokens (rounded down). You also receive {{newTokens}} new tokens. Adjust your strategy based on your results.

visibility.label: Visibility & Insight
visibility.tooltip: How clearly you can see what is happening in your operations in real time

efficiency.label: Efficiency & Throughput
efficiency.tooltip: How smoothly operations and logistics run across your organization

sustainability.label: Sustainability & Emissions
sustainability.tooltip: Energy efficiency, emissions reductions, and resource conservation

earlyWarning.label: Early Warning & Prevention
earlyWarning.tooltip: Ability to detect and prevent problems before they escalate

complexity.label: Complexity & Security Risk
complexity.tooltip: Operational complexity and cybersecurity vulnerabilities from IoT sprawl (lower is better)

warehouseFlow.title: Warehouse Flow Tracking
warehouseFlow.shortDescription: Install tags on pallets, forklifts, and workers. A live map shows where goods are getting stuck and where vehicles idle too long. Based on Logidot's anchor sensors and wearable tags.
warehouseFlow.whenToUse: Use when you need to spot bottlenecks and reduce idling in warehouses or factories.

smartTools.title: Smart Assembly Tools
smartTools.shortDescription: Connected power tools recognize parts automatically and set the right torque. Usage is logged automatically into your system. Inspired by Airbus's assembly line implementation.
smartTools.whenToUse: Use when manual checks are slow and mistakes are costly.

energyMonitoring.title: Energy Monitoring Platform
energyMonitoring.shortDescription: Sensors on every major machine track energy use. You can spot wasteful leaks and remotely power down unused equipment. Based on Bosch's Energy Platform approach.
energyMonitoring.whenToUse: Use when energy costs are high and you suspect hidden waste.

smartBuilding.title: Smart Building Systems
smartBuilding.shortDescription: Dense networks of sensors in lights and vents adjust lighting and heating room by room, minute by minute. Similar to AT&T and Enlighted's building sensor deployment.
smartBuilding.whenToUse: Use when buildings are large, usage patterns vary, and you want energy savings without sacrificing comfort.

fleetOptimization.title: Fleet & Vehicle Optimization
fleetOptimization.shortDescription: Vehicles send data about idling, routes, and fuel use. A central service suggests smarter routes and maintenance schedules. Modeled on Microsoft's Connected Vehicle Platform.
fleetOptimization.whenToUse: Use when you run many vehicles and care about emissions and logistics.

predictiveMaintenance.title: Predictive Maintenance
predictiveMaintenance.shortDescription: Sensors on vehicles and equipment constantly monitor vibration, temperature, and pressure. AI flags issues before breakdowns. Based on Rio Tinto's haul truck monitoring system.
predictiveMaintenance.whenToUse: Use when equipment downtime is very expensive.

digitalTwin.title: Digital Twin of Plant
digitalTwin.shortDescription: Sensors throughout your plant feed a real-time digital model. Engineers can test changes and train remotely before touching real equipment. Inspired by Siemens's desalination plant digital twin.
digitalTwin.whenToUse: Use when you want to see detailed status of a complex facility and experiment safely.

emissionsDetection.title: Emissions Leak Detection
emissionsDetection.shortDescription: Combine on-site sensors and satellite data to detect leaks quickly and reduce emissions. Based on Marathon Oil and GHGSat's methane leak detection system.
emissionsDetection.whenToUse: Use when emissions leaks are critical for regulators, brand, or climate goals.

waterMonitoring.title: Water Infrastructure Monitoring
waterMonitoring.shortDescription: Sensors embedded in dams and water systems deliver real-time information about usage, quality, and early warning of leaks. Similar to Seattle's dam monitoring system.
waterMonitoring.whenToUse: Use when water conservation is a priority or regulatory compliance is required.

gridSensors.title: Power Grid Sensors
gridSensors.shortDescription: Add sensors to power lines to monitor load, ice, and vibrations. Data feeds a digital twin so you see where lines are near capacity. Based on Tensio's grid monitoring technology.
gridSensors.whenToUse: Use when you must understand stress and capacity across a large physical network.

securityHardening.title: IoT Security Hardening
securityHardening.shortDescription: Implement centralized monitoring, automatic updates, and network segmentation to reduce vulnerabilities in your IoT devices.
securityHardening.whenToUse: Use when complexity and security risks are growing faster than your ability to manage them.

healthMonitoring.title: Health & Safety Monitoring
healthMonitoring.shortDescription: Wearable or handheld sensors track health signals (like glucose levels or pressure) and alert staff early so they can intervene. Based on continuous health monitoring devices.
healthMonitoring.whenToUse: Use when worker safety or health monitoring is a priority.

EFFICIENCY_FIRST.title: Efficiency-First Optimizer
EFFICIENCY_FIRST.description: You prioritized throughput and operational efficiency above all else. Your organization runs like a well-oiled machine, but you may have missed opportunities in sustainability and early warning systems.
EFFICIENCY_FIRST.suggestions: Next time, try balancing efficiency gains with environmental impact. Consider predictive maintenance to prevent disruptions.

SUSTAINABILITY_CHAMPION.title: Sustainability Champion
SUSTAINABILITY_CHAMPION.description: You prioritized energy efficiency and emissions reductions, even if it meant slower gains in other areas. Your environmental footprint is significantly reduced.
SUSTAINABILITY_CHAMPION.suggestions: Consider how visibility and early warning systems could help you optimize further. Efficiency and sustainability often reinforce each other.

BALANCED_ARCHITECT.title: Balanced IoT Architect
BALANCED_ARCHITECT.description: You took a measured approach, improving multiple dimensions without over-investing in any single area. Your strategy is sustainable and well-rounded.
BALANCED_ARCHITECT.suggestions: You demonstrated strong strategic thinking. Try pushing one dimension to excellence to see the full potential.

OVER_CONNECTED_RISK_TAKER.title: Over-Connected Risk-Taker
OVER_CONNECTED_RISK_TAKER.description: You deployed IoT aggressively across your organization, but complexity and security risks grew faster than your ability to manage them. You're collecting lots of data but may struggle to act on it safely.
OVER_CONNECTED_RISK_TAKER.suggestions: Security hardening and strategic simplification would help. Sometimes less IoT, deployed more thoughtfully, delivers better results.

EARLY_WARNING_GUARDIAN.title: Early-Warning Guardian
EARLY_WARNING_GUARDIAN.description: You invested heavily in predictive systems and preventive monitoring. Your organization can now catch problems before they become crises, saving significant costs.
EARLY_WARNING_GUARDIAN.suggestions: Strong choice for risk mitigation. Consider how visibility and efficiency initiatives could compound these benefits.

VISIBILITY_FOCUSED.title: Visibility-Focused Strategist
VISIBILITY_FOCUSED.description: You prioritized seeing everything that's happening across your operations. Digital twins and monitoring give you unprecedented insight.
VISIBILITY_FOCUSED.suggestions: Excellent foundation. Now consider how to act on all that visibility—through automation, optimization, or predictive systems.

welcome.title: Welcome to IoT Strategy Sprint!
welcome.description: In this game, you'll learn IoT fundamentals by making strategic investment decisions. Let's walk through how it works.

metrics.title: Understanding Metrics
metrics.description: These five metrics track your organization's performance. Your goal is to improve visibility, efficiency, sustainability, and early warning while keeping complexity low.

tokens.title: Token System
tokens.description: Each year you receive tokens to invest. Allocate them wisely across different IoT initiatives to improve your metrics.

cards.title: Initiative Cards
cards.description: Each card represents a real-world IoT solution. Click the info button to see how it affects the IoT process loop (Sense, Share, Process, Act).

allocation.title: Allocating Tokens
allocation.description: Use the +/- buttons or arrow keys to add tokens to each card. You can allocate up to 3 tokens per initiative. More tokens = stronger effect, but watch for diminishing returns.

glossary.title: IoT Glossary
glossary.description: Not sure what a term means? Click the book icon in the top bar to open the IoT Glossary. It explains key concepts like Digital Twin, Edge Computing, and more with real-world examples.

ready.title: You're Ready!
ready.description: Make strategic choices, learn from feedback, and see how your IoT strategy shapes the organization. Good luck!

glossary.title: IoT Glossary
glossary.description: Key terms and concepts to help you understand IoT strategy

digitalTwin.definition: A virtual replica of a physical asset, process, or system that receives real-time data from sensors. It allows you to monitor, analyze, and simulate the physical counterpart without touching it.
digitalTwin.example: A factory creates a digital twin of its production line. Engineers can test changes virtually before implementing them, reducing downtime and risk.

predictiveMaintenance.definition: Using sensor data and analytics to predict when equipment will fail, allowing maintenance before breakdowns occur. This reduces unplanned downtime and extends equipment life.
predictiveMaintenance.example: Sensors on a conveyor belt motor detect increasing vibration patterns. The system alerts maintenance to replace bearings before the motor fails.

sensor.definition: A device that detects physical properties (temperature, motion, light, pressure) and converts them into signals that can be read by systems. Sensors are the 'eyes and ears' of IoT.
sensor.example: Temperature sensors in a warehouse track cold storage conditions, alerting staff if temperatures rise above safe levels.

edgeComputing.definition: Processing data near where it's collected (at the 'edge' of the network) rather than sending everything to a central server. This reduces latency and bandwidth usage.
edgeComputing.example: A security camera analyzes video locally to detect motion, only sending alerts rather than streaming all footage continuously.

iotDevice.definition: Any physical object embedded with sensors, software, and connectivity that allows it to collect and exchange data over the internet. From smart thermostats to industrial machines.
iotDevice.example: Smart light bulbs that can be controlled remotely and report energy usage are IoT devices.

realTimeData.definition: Information that is collected, processed, and delivered immediately as events occur. This enables instant visibility and rapid response to changing conditions.
realTimeData.example: A fleet management system shows the exact location of every delivery truck at this moment, not where they were an hour ago.

connectivity.definition: The ability of devices to connect to networks and communicate data. This includes Wi-Fi, cellular, Bluetooth, and specialized industrial protocols.
connectivity.example: Sensors in a remote oil field use cellular connectivity to send data back to headquarters hundreds of miles away.

machineLearning.definition: AI techniques that allow systems to learn patterns from data and make predictions or decisions without explicit programming. Used in IoT for anomaly detection and prediction.
machineLearning.example: An ML model learns normal vibration patterns of a pump and can detect when vibrations indicate an upcoming failure.

automation.definition: Using technology to perform tasks with minimal human intervention. In IoT, this often means systems that respond automatically to sensor data.
automation.example: When motion sensors detect no one in a room for 10 minutes, lights automatically turn off to save energy.

iotSprawl.definition: The uncontrolled growth of IoT devices across an organization, leading to management complexity, security vulnerabilities, and difficulty maintaining oversight.
iotSprawl.example: A company finds it has 500+ connected devices from 20 different vendors, many running outdated firmware with unknown security status.

networkSegmentation.definition: Dividing a network into isolated segments to limit the spread of security breaches. Critical for IoT security to prevent compromised devices from accessing sensitive systems.
networkSegmentation.example: Factory floor sensors are on a separate network from office computers, so a hacked sensor can't access financial data.

latency.definition: The delay between when data is sent and when it arrives. Low latency is critical for real-time applications where quick response is essential.
latency.example: In autonomous vehicles, sensor data must have extremely low latency—even a 100ms delay could cause an accident.
